docs.lead_paragraph: Later, in one of those comically solemn conclaves at which journalists ponder the philosophy of their trade and eat high on the expense account, the news industry will struggle to understand the Great Media Meltdown of 1998. If I am asked to contribute a monograph, it will tend toward the theory that something akin to road rage occurred in the Washington press corps.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker Op-Ed column holds Washington press corp suffered something akin to road rage in coverage of Monica Lewinsky scandal, producing actions that were foolish, shameful, dangerous to American democracy and destructive to news industry's image; sees undiminished public support for Clinton spurring effort by frustrated media to destroy him (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A luxury rental apartment building that will be a commanding presence in its low-rise East Side neighborhood is now under construction and will eventually rise 48 stories above the pavement at 10 East 29th Street. The $105 million building, known as the Madison Belvedere, will have 400 studio to two-bedroom apartments, many with balconies and unobstructed city views. It will take shape on a vacant midblock lot between Madison and Fifth Avenues opposite the landmark 19th-century Church of the Transfiguration, also known as the Little Church Around the Corner.

headline.main: Residential Real Estate; A 48-Story Tower for a Low-Rise Neighborhood

docs.abstract: Luxury rental apartment building is under construction and will rise 48 stories above pavement at 10 East 29th Street, in area of mostly low-rise buildings; building, known as Madison Belvedere, will have 400 studio to two-bedroom apartments; developer is Rose Associates; architect's rendering (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today, setting up a confrontation with President Clinton over how the nation should take advantage of its return to fiscal health. Defying Mr. Clinton's insistence that projected Federal budget surpluses be set aside until Congress and the Administration have settled on a plan to shore up Social Security, the committee voted 23 to 15, largely along party lines, to dip into the surplus to pay for a package of tax reductions likely to have broad appeal to the middle class.

headline.main: House Panel Approves Republicans' $80 Billion Tax Cut Plan

docs.abstract: House Ways and Means Committee, voting mostly along party lines, approves $80-billion Republican tax cut, defying Pres Clinton's insistence that projected budget surpluses be set aside until Social Security is shored up; Democrats admit being sorely tempted to support for tax cut because of upcoming election, and because it has provisions they support; bill is tailored to have broad middle class appeal, addressing marriage penalty for two-income couples (M)
docs.snippet: The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today, setting up a confrontation with President Clinton over how the nation should take advantage of its return to fiscal health.    Defying Mr. Clinton's insistence that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking unilateral action while Congress squabbles over legislation, President Clinton will announce new consumer protections on Thursday for more than 15 million Medicaid patients in health maintenance organizations. The new rules range from a requirement that H.M.O.'s allow women to have direct access to obstetricians and gynecologists, without getting a referral or prior authorization, to a guarantee that health plans will pay for emergency services whenever a ''prudent lay person'' would consider them necessary.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, acting while Congress squabbles over legislation, plans to announce new consumer protections for over 15 million Medicaid patience in health maintenance organizations; rules range from requirement that HMO's allow women direct access to obstetricians and gynecologists, without referral or prior authorization, to requirement that plans pay for emergency services that would be deemed necessary by 'prudent lay person;' Senate Republicans, led by Sen Trent Lott, use series of parliamentary maneuvers to block consideration of patients' rights bill proposed by Sen Tom Daschle (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration announced today that it was relaxing export controls for encryption software used by several industries, including certain medical, insurance and on-line commerce companies. The announcement, made at the White House by Vice President Al Gore, is another concession to industry and even some agencies within the Federal Government that have been pushing the Administration to relax export controls on data-scrambling technologies, despite the Justice Department's insistence that controls remain tight.

headline.main: U.S. Eases Encryption Software Export Bans

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration announces that it is relaxing export controls for encryption software used by several industries; announcement, made at White House by Vice Pres Al Gore, is another concession to industry and even some agencies within Federal Government that have been pushing Administration to relax export controls on data-scrambling technologies, despite Justice Department's insistence that controls remain tight (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Barbara B. Kennelly, whose Democratic campaign for governor has never caught fire, caught a break in the primary on Tuesday when voters gave her a running mate who excites party members. Democrats scrambled today to try to enjoy the lift from the nomination of Denise L. Nappier, who will run with Mrs. Kennelly on Nov. 3 as the Democratic candidate for treasurer. As an African-American and the lone minority candidate on the Democratic slate, Ms. Nappier could help her party hold on to its traditional constituencies in a year when Republicans have been bragging about fielding three minority candidates.

headline.main: Kennelly Got Running Mate She Wanted in the Primary

docs.abstract: Connecticut Democrats say that primary victory of Denise L Nappier for Treasurer will give Barbara B Kennelly, whose Democratic campaign for governor has never caught fire, a big boost; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Plotting a course after its merger with United Healthcare fell apart, Humana Inc. is pulling out of unprofitable markets. Humana, of Louisville, Ky., said yesterday that it would exit Sarasota and Treasure Coast, Fla., and Springfield and Jefferson City, Mo. It also said it would take a $132 million charge against earnings -- $84 million after taxes -- for the quarter that ends on Sept. 30. The charges include an expected $63 million cost for exiting the markets and $52 million for asset write-offs, costs related to Humana's contractual relationships with various physician practice-management companies and merger dissolution costs. Its shares rose 18.75 cents, to $14.6875.

headline.main: HUMANA IS PULLING OUT OF SOME UNPROFITABLE MARKETS

docs.abstract: Humana Inc is pulling out of unprofitable markets; Humana will exit Sarasota and Treasure Coast, Fla, and Springfield and Jefferson City, Mo; it will take $132 million charge against earnings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The heavy retreat by health maintenance organizations from providing Medicare to the elderly and disabled (Business Day, Sept. 9) demonstrates the need to maintain strong public programs that will provide health benefits when there are no more profits for the private sector.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Rising drug costs, increased consumer demand, legislative mandates and the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 are external forces that have contributed to health maintenance organization woes (Business Day, Sept. 9). However, difficulty in pushing full financial risk directly onto providers, inadequate investment in information systems, an adversarial stance toward doctors and hospitals, delay in the integration of mergers, poor resource allocation for consumer education and failure to deliver on the hyped quality and outcomes-based care are the root causes of their current dismay.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Sunil S Jhangiani disputes September 9 Business Day article on root causes of current problems of health maintenance organizations (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's largest union will announce an unusual agreement today with the Rite Aid pharmacy chain in which the union's health-care plan will steer tens of millions of dollars in business to Rite Aid and other unionized drug stores. In return, Rite Aid Corporation has promised not to fight organizing drives by the union, 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, as 1199 sets out to unionize dozens more Rite Aid stores in the New York area.

headline.main: Union Will Steer Members to Rite Aid in Return for Promise Not to Fight Organizing Drives

docs.abstract: Local 1199 of National Health and Human Services Employees Union, New York City's largest union, will announce unusual agreement with Rite Aid pharmacy chain in which union's health-care plan will steer tens of millions of dollars in business to Rite Aid and other unionized drug stores; in return, Rite Aid Corp has promised not to fight organizing drives by union at dozens of Rite Aid stores in New York area (M)
